description: From Middle English condempnen, from Old French condamner, from Latin condemnāre (“to sentence, condemn, blame”), from com- + damnāre (“to harm, condemn, damn”), from damnum (“damage, injury, loss”). Displaced native Middle English fordemen (from Old English fordeman (“condemn, sentence, doom”) > Modern English fordeem.

verbs.description: condemn (third-person singular simple present condemns, present participle condemning, simple past and past participle condemned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strongly criticise or denounce; to excoriate the perpetrators of.
(transitive) To judicially announce a verdict upon a finding of guilt; To sentence
examples: The judge condemned him to death.
She was condemned to life in prison.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To confer eternal divine punishment upon.
(transitive) To adjudge (a building) as being unfit for habitation.
examples: The house was condemned after it was badly damaged by fire.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adjudge (building or construction work) as of unsatisfactory quality, requiring the work to be redone.
(transitive) To adjudge (food or drink) as being unfit for human consumption.
To declare something to be unfit for use, or further use.
(transitive) To determine and declare (property) to be assigned to public use. See eminent domain.
(transitive, law) To declare (a vessel) to be forfeited to the government, to be a prize, or to be unfit for service.
